awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Calibration of Thermochemical Models using Bayesian Methods--Building MELTS 2.0.
awd_abstract_narration:
Molten rocks are essential to the structure and long-term evolution of the Earth and other planets.  The properties of rocks when heated above their melting point (including composition, density, heat content, and thermal expansion) all play important roles in a vast array of geologic processes. These range widely from the creation of deep magma oceans during the earliest stages of planet formation all the way to the steady progress of plate tectonics, responsible for creating, shaping, and destroying the Earth's oceans and continents.  Unfortunately, these geologic processes occur over planetary length-scales and time-scales, playing out over thousands of kilometers and billions of years.  Due to this complexity, it is not possible to perform experiments that directly probe the evolution of planetary interiors. Instead, scientist rely upon thermodynamic models, which can predict the physical and energetic properties of rocks, melts, and fluids based on the results of laboratory experiments performed under controlled conditions.  The usefulness of these models thus depends entirely upon how well they are calibrated, including the amount and variety of experimental data as well as the statistical methods used to extract the thermodynamic modeling parameters.  In this proposal, the team will develop new modeling techniques needed to improve and extend the geologic thermodynamic models used to predict the properties of solid and molten rocks at planetary conditions, relevant to our understanding of rocky planets both within and outside our solar system.

To accomplish these overarching goals, the collaborators will design the analytic tools needed to construct flexible and robust self-consistent thermodynamic models for the geologic community using Bayesian statistical methods.  Currently, the calibration procedure for thermodynamic databases (like the popular MELTS model) is an unfortunately onerous task.  Updating these models is time-consuming and restricted to the very few experts with the skills required to integrate new information without breaking the accuracy and self-consistency of the model.  The purpose of this proposal is to dramatically reduce the challenges associated with recalibration, enabling simple and rapid incorporation of new experimental data into the database by a wide variety of users.  The proposal objectives are: (1) Design and create statistical calibration tools (using novel Bayesian techniques) to simplify thermochemical model building; (2) Expand and augment the calibration database with the large quantity of previously ignored data, including solid phase-absent constraints, melt-free sub-solidus experiments, and observations of melt coexisting with solid phases of unmeasured-composition; (3) Use the new methods and data to produce MELTS 2.0, a new tunable silicate melts model that provides model prediction uncertainties, enabling users to rapidly pinpoint and address model weaknesses.  The resulting calibration tool will thus be able to generate and visualize model prediction distributions - useful for geologic process modeling, teaching, and future experimental planning -and help to close the large gap that still exists between model-use and model-design.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the creation of a new thermochemical model of igneous volcanic systems, MELTS 2.0, along with an open source scientific framework (as part of the ENKI project) for developing and applying such models in geological simulations. Our new model MELTS 2.0 makes major improvements upon existing thermochemical magma models in three major areas: 

(1) Modern (Bayesian) Statistical Techniques: The development (or calibration) of MELTS 2.0 relies upon Bayesian statistical analysis, allowing the model to fully quantify uncertainties in model parameters and use them in Monte Carlo (probabilistic) simulations to provide fully automated and customized assessments of accuracy & robustness for any simulated geological application.

(2) Open Source Thermodynamic Modeling Framework: The MELTS 2.0 model is fully integrated into the open-source “thermoengine” python package (developed with combined support from this grant and a separate NSF grant that established the ENKI project, www.enki-portal.org) allowing it to be used interchangeably and compared with past MELTS models. The MELTS 2.0 calibration is stored within a public repository that provides a fully transparent and reproducible pipeline for how the model is calibrated, assessed, and applied (made possible with additional support from an NSF-EarthCube grant) enabling researchers to easily validate and expand upon this work with new data or alternative modeling assumptions, and thus fully supporting the NSF’s increasing demand for open and reproducible science.

(3) Accurate Redox-Sensitive Melt Properties: MELTS 2.0 is the first model of its kind to incorporate previously neglected oxygen redox constraints, producing the first thermochemical model of silicate melting that accurately captures how oxygen availability (fO2) impacts the composition and energetics of the melt, directly addressing one of the most important controlling factors over mantle melting and magmatic evolution.

All of the software and modeling tools produced over the course of this grant have been made available in public code repositories, enabling other researchers to build upon the existing work. Beyond the major milestones listed above, this grant has also supported other significant developments in thermodynamic modeling of silicate melts. By combining support from this grant and an external NASA grant, the MELTS family of liquid models has been expanded into an open-source model for magma ocean and volcanic outgassing (VapoRock) and has been published and is gaining users especially within the exoplanet community. Additionally, we have developed a simplified open-source tool for magma evolution simulation and visualization (MagmaForge) that also provides straightforward uncertainty visualizations for simulations run using the MELTS 2.0 model. These and related works were likewise shared openly with the geological modeling community, not only through presentations at society meetings (including AGU, Goldschmidt, & AAS) but also through workshops for the ENKI project that hosted potential users and developers of these new thermodynamic modeling tools, with invited participants dominated by early career scientists (grad students, postdocs, and untenured professors).  With this grant, we aimed to disrupt the standard model-builder/model-user hierarchy, instead empowering a new group of thermodynamic user-developers who take an active role in not only the application of thermodynamic models, but their development, maintenance, and extension as well. Indeed, a number of these participants have continued collaborations related to this work and have begun incorporating these software tools into undergrad and graduate courses, as well as developing and releasing new open-source modeling tools that build upon the existing framework.

Thermochemical model-building has always been a long and laborious process, involving intense special-purpose coding efforts, typically taking years to produce a single best-fit model. The combination of unavoidably strong correlations in model parameters and the thermodynamic significance of subtle variations in energy has always meant that updates, tweaks, or expansions to past models has been slow and fraught with error, often requiring wholesale recalibration with all the time and energy that involves. This grant supported the work to open up an entirely new path. We now have generalized reusable and open-source software that automates many of these steps. The analysis is done entirely in a reproducible pipeline of automated scripts. And the final result is a complete family of model parameters consistent with experimental and theoretical constraints. Subsequent modifications to the model are dramatically simpler, with fully quantified model parameter uncertainties in hand, and full recalibration requires only modifying the calibration pipeline. The future of geological thermodynamic model building is more open, more reproducible, more accessible, and more inclusive than it has ever been.
